Question
========
You survey a wetland and estimate that the probability a randomly chosen quadrat contains cattails is 0.65. Which interpretation is most appropriate under the frequentist definition of probability?

Answerlist
----------
* Exactly 65% of all quadrats always contain cattails
* In the long run, about 65% of randomly sampled quadrats would contain cattails
* There are exactly 65 cattails per quadrat
* Cattails are guaranteed to be present in every wetland

Solution
========
A probability like 0.65 describes **uncertainty** and is often interpreted as a longâ€‘run frequency by frequentists. That is, if you repeatedly sample many quadrats under similar conditions, you would expect cattails in about 65% of them **on average**. It does **not** mean you will get exactly 65% in every small sample, it does not describe abundance (how many cattails), and it does not guarantee they will be present in every wetland.
